topics.title: Matrix
content: A matrix is a rectangular arrangement of numbers in rows and columns.
It is written as m×n, where m = rows, n = columns.

topics.title: Types of Matrices
content: Row Matrix → Only one row. Example: [1 2 3]
Column Matrix → Only one column. Example: [4;5;6]
Diagonal Matrix → Non-zero only on the main diagonal. Example: [[5,0],[0,7]]
Scalar Matrix → Diagonal matrix with equal diagonal elements. Example: [[3,0],[0,3]]
Zero Matrix → All elements are zero. Example: [[0,0],[0,0]]
Upper Triangular Matrix → Elements below diagonal = 0. Example: [[1,2,3],[0,4,5],[0,0,6]]
Lower Triangular Matrix → Elements above diagonal = 0. Example: [[1,0,0],[4,5,0],[7,8,9]]

topics.title: Matrix Operations
content: Scalar Multiplication → Multiply each element by a constant.
Matrix Multiplication → Row × Column rule (cols of 1st = rows of 2nd).
Determinant → Scalar value for a square matrix. Example: |[a b; c d]| = ad - bc

topics.title: Properties of Matrix Operations
content: Multiplication: Associative, Distributive, Not commutative, Identity
Transpose: (A+B)ᵀ = Aᵀ + Bᵀ, (AB)ᵀ = Bᵀ Aᵀ, (Aᵀ)ᵀ = A

topics.title: Eigenvalues & Eigenvectors
content: Eigenvectors are special vectors whose direction does not change when multiplied by a matrix.

topics.title: Equivalent Matrices
content: Two matrices are equivalent if one can be obtained from the other by elementary row/column operations.
Equivalent matrices have the same rank.

topics.title: Elementary Row Operations
content: Uses: finding rank, echelon form, solving linear equations

topics.title: Rank of a Matrix (Normal Form)
content: Rank = number of non-zero rows after reducing to normal form.
Steps: Apply row/column operations, convert to normal form, count independent rows.

topics.title: Rank of a Matrix (Echelon Form)
content: Echelon form: non-zero rows above zero rows, pivots to the right, zeros below pivots.
Steps: Apply row operations → echelon form → count non-zero rows.
